data.title: Markdown preview is broken in 1.3.0 release
data.body:

- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a markdown file
2. the magnifier glass for preview is absent on the top right 

see also #8130 

`Ctrl+Shift+V` works fine

data.title: Duplicate search results after using "Go to definition" with C language
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.14 LTS
- Microsoft C/C++ extension installed

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a folder (eg "/home/user/src")
2. Use Go to definition or Peek definition on any symbol
3. Search something with the search panel (ctrl+shift+f)
4. Get duplicate results from the _same file with two different paths:_
/home/user/src/src.c
///home/user/src/src.c

data.title: TSX code formatter behaves incorrectly after encountering type arguments
Inconsistent colorization of multiline union and intersection types
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
I'm using Dark+ (default dark) theme but some other themes have same issue:
![vscode-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1395677/16736118/1bb9499e-47a5-11e6-9180-0651db9177ff.png)

As you can see `B` and `C` are never colorized in multiline declarations and `A` is colorized in some cases. Same for string literal types.

data.title: support font-size in DecorationRenderOptions

data.body: Feature request: support specifying the font size in `DecorationRenderOptions` and `ThemableDecorationAttachmentRenderOptions`.

data.title: Be more explicit on what we expect from pull requests
data.body:
In order to avoid wasted effort such as in #7563, we should be more explicit on pull requests [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests):
- Note that it may require discussion unless there is an explicit verbal call for a PR or has the help-wanted label. A GitHub issue may be a feature request, but it may not be a _valid_ feature request given the direction of the product and need to keep everything light and responsive.
- Note importance of code organization page?

Sub-tasks:
- [x] Update how to contribute wiki page
- [ ] Add PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md

data.title: Even edited tabs I want to stay open go to "temporary" status and get closed if I open something else.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Win7 Enterprise x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Have tabs opened.  Edit them so the tab title should not be italics.
2.  Open something else, breathe, anything, click out and back in to a window, etc., and magically the tab you have focused now has an italics title and if you don't notice right away and open something else, the italics-titled tab naturally goes away.  (I honestly spent most of Friday trying to figure out a reason or rhyme for what triggers this bug, but I have no idea.)

This wouldn't be annoying if I didn't have gigantic PHP files I'd just spent a long while collapsing stuff on so I could scroll it easier; I have to re-do that every time I have to reopen the file.  It's frustrating enough to make me consider going back to Sublime :(

data.title: Broken Markdown Syntax Highlighting since 1.3.0
data.body:
EDIT: most of these issues appear to be from 1.3.0. If I try the same files in an earlier version of code, they look closer to those in the atom examples. I added a pre 1.3.0 VSCode image to example 2. None of the other issues such as bold, italics, html, code blocks, or anything else have issues in earlier versions. These all seem to have been introduced recently when making markdown its own language I am guessing.

I use markdown for writing documentation and blog posts, and this is the one thing keeping me from 100% moving to VSCode. The syntax is so poor that I have to continue using atom for things like blog posts, which is ironic since half my posts these days are about VSCode. I am adding a few pictures to show how bad VSCode is in comparison to Atom and point out some of the areas that need improvement.
## Example 1

VSCode
![vscodemarkdown](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/16732906/e9226dd6-4744-11e6-8309-9a542d6b88ce.png)
Atom
![atommarkdown](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/16732930/043b1096-4745-11e6-815c-ecb307e3531d.png)
## Example 2

VSCode Pre 1.3.0
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/16735454/b49cfdc4-474e-11e6-875c-dd1744a8e80f.png)
VSCode
![vscodemarkdown2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/16732953/10a011f6-4745-11e6-87a7-c69dbeee6574.png)
Atom
![atommarkdown2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/16732964/1a270522-4745-11e6-9ba2-18dcc22fc320.png)

You get the same poor results in pretty much every theme. 

A few of the issues that stand out:
- adding bold or italics to a list breaks the coloring.
  ![bolditalics](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/16733515/7c2a2fea-4747-11e6-9a8b-05ce0673bbca.png)
- Lists should appear like Atom with only the bullet being colored as seen in example 2 above.
- Lists for sections like Jekyll blogs should properly highlight similar to Atom.
  ![atomlistjekyll](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/16733658/147b92c0-4748-11e6-98d9-45b99adb6835.png)
  ![listjekyll](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/16733665/18d6b73c-4748-11e6-9e8a-760d2af5a802.png)
- Having multiple bold or italics words in the same line breaks the rest of the document.
  ![vscodehtml](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/16733830/c2a91d9a-4748-11e6-8ae6-c934f0e36b7a.png)
  ![atomhtml](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/16733833/c58f1b54-4748-11e6-96ed-3cb465e6310f.png)
- Small amounts of html like <kdb> it can't handle if in a list
  ![vscodehtmllist](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/16733951/4dc39608-4749-11e6-9971-ceef68976b3c.png)
- Lists break any syntax coloring in the line.
  ![atomsyntaxlist](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/16734057/bb391c94-4749-11e6-9efb-36a3b17d9ed7.png)
  ![vscodesyntaxlist](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/16734071/c7d1bcb8-4749-11e6-915a-8f0ad6b9a734.png)

There are likely some other issues, but they are escaping me right now. I will try to update this if I can remember any others.
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Compare 2 theme between Atom and VSCode

data.title: Dragging and Dropping a folder from file explorer doesn't work.
data.body:
- VSCode `Version:1.3
- OS Version:Win 7 64bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VS Code
2. Open File Explorer
3. Drag a folder from file explorer to VS Code editor pane.

In previous versions of VS Code you could drag and drop folders to the editor pane in VS Code to open them.  As of 1.3 this functionality no longer works.  Nothing in the release notes says that this was removed, only that the drag and drop was enhanced.

data.title: Autocomplete for "console.log()" in JavaScript and TypeScript is wrong.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0 (1.3.0)
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5 (15F34)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. type console.l
2. Press tab to autocomplete
3. the result is "console.console.log();"

It looks like not the method "log" is autocompleted but the entire class + function.

data.title: SCSS formatter doesn't work anymore
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. SHIFT + ALT + F in an SCSS file

Hello,

This was working before but not it stopped. Tried installing plugins, etc. Still nothing. 

Thanks

data.title: Closing split view prompts to discard saved changes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open any file, make some changes to it (don't save)
2. Split the editor
3. Make more changes; close one of the splits and choose "Don't save" -- changes are reverted even though the file is still open and in plain sight.

It makes sense that the changes are discarded since I said Don't save, but it does not make sense that I should have been prompted that at all.

Don't quote me on this (I didn't test it) but I have a feeling this is a regression.  I feel like I've done this all the time.  I quickly tested by disabling tabs and still get the same result though.

data.title: Feature Request: Right Click -> Copy Path on file list
data.body:
It would be really helpful to copy the path of a file. For example, if I search for something and a file is pulled up, with a long and complex path, it would be good to capture that, see below:

[![enter image description here](http://i.stack.imgur.com/hanic.png)](http://i.stack.imgur.com/hanic.png)

Being able to right click (ctrl + click on mac) on the file (which I am hovering over in the picture) and copy the file path would be really handy.

data.title: .tsx code format broken
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.4.0-insider (f6227ca157caed3ce3224ad9f760a8d5c8ed0e4d, 2016-07-11T05:07:20.965Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open new VSCODE
2. Paste kode from file [Configurations.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/356989/Configurations.txt) into Untitled-1
3. Save as e.g. "test.tsx"
4. Jump to line 1457
5. Press Alt + Shift + F or run format code command
6. Nothing happens - code is still the same (i believe the format code service dies here)
7. Create a new .tsx file make some simple typescript, e.g.

```
function(test:string)
   {
      let example      =   test;
   } 
```
1. Press Alt + Shift + F and nothing happens. You need to restart VSCode to run "Format Code" again

/Michael

Follow up from #7839

data.title: (Linux, V1.3) Cannot install extensions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-1467909982
- OS Version: Linux Mint 17.3 (Ubuntu 14.04 based)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install version 1.2
2. Update to version 1.2.1
3. Update to version 1.3
4. Click extension icon
5. Search for "eslint" (for example)
6. Click on "install"
7. Nothing happens, but errors show in Developer tools.

Error in developer tools:

shell.ts:416 Cannot read property 'call' of undefined: TypeError: Cannot read property 'call' of undefined,    at e.onCommonRequest (/usr/share/code/resources/app/out/vs/code/node/sharedProcessMain.js:6:20045),    at e.onMessage (/usr/share/code/resources/app/out/vs/code/node/sharedProcessMain.js:6:19889),    at /usr/share/code/resources/app/out/vs/code/node/sharedProcessMain.js:6:19697,    at Socket.<anonymous> (/usr/share/code/resources/app/out/vs/code/node/sharedProcessMain.js:6:23531),    at emitOne (events.js:90:13),    at Socket.emit (events.js:182:7),    at readableAddChunk (_stream_readable.js:153:18),    at Socket.Readable.push (_stream_readable.js:111:10),    at Pipe.onread (net.js:531:20)e.onUnexpectedError @ shell.ts:416(anonymous function) @ shell.ts:318e.onUnexpectedError @ errors.ts:73u @ errors.ts:88(anonymous function) @ winjs.base.js:43(anonymous function) @ winjs.base.js:38
winjs.base.js:45 WARNING: Promise with no error callback:46
winjs.base.js:46 Object {exception: null, error: Error: Cannot read property 'call' of undefined, promise: i.Cs.de._oncancel, handler: undefined, id: 46}
winjs.base.js:45 WARNING: Promise with no error callback:47
winjs.base.js:46 Object {exception: null, error: Error: Cannot read property 'call' of undefined, promise: i.Cs.de._oncancel, handler: undefined, id: 47}

It seems that version 1.2 was called visual-studio-code and version 1.3 is called code so both are installed simultaneously. Removing version 1.2 does not make a difference.

Workaround: 
1. Remove version 1.3, 
2. Install version 1.2.1 & start application
3. ctrl-P, type ?  (typing ext install directly will not work)
4. select "Extension install"
5. Search & install the wanted extensions
6. close application
7. Install version 1.3
8. Extensions are installed and working

data.title: How to show errors in the editor
data.body:
Followup from #8836:

@isidorn we have already examples for how to show these kind of errors. 
When trying to open a huge file, the error is shown like this:

![2016-07-11_11-22-21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/16725950/0ab2069a-475a-11e6-9f91-e3c01e29b172.png)

We should align with that approach; ideally we should share the implementation.

data.title: Debt: Support launch.json creation through extension host code
data.body:
Currently an extension can only contribute an initial launch.json statically, so it cannot adapt the launch.json to the contents or structure of an existing project folder.

For node.js we work around this in VS Code by specific code that understands the package.json.
With this feature we could move this code from VS Code into node-debug.

data.title: [scss] syntax highlighting breaks after nested braces
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insider f6227ca
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro Insider 14385

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a SCSS file. Note that syntax highlighting works.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1077648/16724906/d136291e-4709-11e6-9d0e-6d51b92a0bb7.png)
1. Add any level of nested braces within. Note that syntax highlighting works inside the nested braces:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1077648/16724891/b5fd051e-4709-11e6-9cb3-4e94b708a1a6.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1077648/16724936/f039c8f2-4709-11e6-82e1-81c3cfb7fa9f.png)
1. Add more code after the nested braces. Syntax highlighting is now broken for code after the braces.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1077648/16724898/c2049e12-4709-11e6-8e63-aa08fb3c77c4.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1077648/16724959/01999618-470a-11e6-830c-49e3f2cdadab.png)
